Yeah... it sure as hell wasn’t what I expected. Thought I’d see some colors, maybe cry a little, get a pat on the back and fly home fixed. Instead... I got my ass handed to me in ways I didn’t know I needed.

First night, I saw the cockpit again—except this time I wasn’t flying. I was strapped in the seat, engines screaming, and the controls weren’t responding. I wasn’t in charge anymore. Couldn’t outrank the memory. Couldn’t muscle through it. Just had to sit there and feel it. All of it. Every second I thought I’d die, every second I thought I’d failed the guys counting on me.

And then... then I saw Amanda. Not the version I come home to now—tense, quiet, walking on eggshells. I saw her the way she used to look at me. Like I was her safe place. And I realized I’d turned into the thing she needed protection from.

I puked my guts out after that one. Felt like I was coughing up more than ayahuasca. Felt like I was purging every time I told her “I’m fine” when I wasn’t. Every night I rolled over and pretended I hadn’t been shouting in my sleep.

Second night, I met my brothers. Not just the ones we lost—though yeah, they were there—but the part of me still flying cover for them. Still trying to earn the right to come home. Still trying to be the last man standing so nobody else had to. And the medicine... it asked me: “Who told you you had to carry the whole war by yourself?”

I didn’t have an answer. Just sobbed like a damn kid. Felt like someone pulled shrapnel out of my chest I didn’t know was there.

Third night was quieter. I didn’t see much. Just... sat in a field. Stars overhead. No engines. No radios. No mission. Just breathing. And for the first time in fifteen years, I felt like maybe I wasn’t behind enemy lines anymore.

I’m not fixed. I know that. But something’s different. I looked Amanda in the eyes when I got back, and I didn’t feel the need to look away. I told her I love her. Didn’t mumble it. Didn’t tack on a joke or a grunt. Just said it. Like I meant it. Because I do.

So... yeah. The medicine did its work. Now I guess I gotta do mine.
